subject: Medicine
title: Edward Jenner and Vaccination
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Edward Jenner and Vaccination.

hook.text: A country doctor noticed milkmaids who caught cowpox never got smallpox. He tested a wild theory.

buildup.text: Edward Jenner scratched cowpox pus into a boy's arm in 1796. Six weeks later, he exposed him to smallpox.

discovery.text: The boy didn't get sick. Cowpox had trained his body to fight the deadly virus.

twist.text: Jenner didn't know why it worked. Immune science wouldn't exist for another century.

climax.text: His discovery led to the complete eradication of smallpoxâ€”the only disease humans have ever eliminated.

punchline.text: A milkmaid's rash ended humanity's deadliest plague.

quiz.question: What observation led Jenner to develop vaccination?
options: Milkmaids with cowpox never got smallpox
Children exposed to chickenpox became immune
Doctors who treated plague patients didn't get sick
